Productive human immunodeficiency virus type 1 ( HIV-1 ) infection causes sustained NF-kappaB DNA - binding activity in chronically infected monocytic cells .
A direct temporal correlation exists between HIV infection and the appearance of NF-kappaB DNA - binding activity in myelomonoblastic PLB-985 cells .

To examine the molecular basis of constitutive NF-kappaB DNA - binding activity in HIV1 - infected cells , we analyzed the phosphorylation and turnover of <extra_id_0> IkappaBalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein , the activity of the <extra_id_0> double-stranded RNA-dependent protein kinase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> PKR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and the intracellular levels of NF-kappaB subunits in the PLB-985 and U937 myeloid cell models .
HIV-1 infection resulted in constitutive , low - level expression of type 1 interferon ( IFN ) at the mRNA level .

Constitutive <extra_id_0> PKR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activity was also detected in HIV-1-infected cells as a result of low - level IFN production , since the addition of anti-IFN-alpha / beta antibody to the cells decreased <extra_id_0> PKR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression .

We suggest that HIV-1 infection of myeloid cells induces IFN production and <extra_id_0> PKR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activity , which in turn contribute to enhanced <extra_id_0> IkappaBalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> phosphorylation and subsequent degradation .
